content.webTitle: 'I was fed up of being told it's a man's game': why more women are playing football

fields.headline: 'I was fed up of being told it's a man's game': why more women are playing football
fields.bodyText: Polly Simpson, treasurer of the women’s football team Goal Diggers, has the simple task of posting the sign-up list for training and matches each week. But as the club has grown from a handful of players in 2015 to more than 150 now, Simpson’s administrative responsibilities can no longer be described as mundane. Pitch space limits the number who can train to 60, and the list often fills up within seconds. “I get so stressed because I have to put it on at the exact right time,” the 25-year-old says. When one player realised what time it was, she jumped off a train and tried to get signal so she could sign up. “It’s like getting tickets for Glastonbury.” Simpson believes the club’s growth is evidence that when women are given a welcoming space in which to play football, they will come and play. Goal Diggers, which is open to women and non-binary players, is one of a handful of new grassroots football clubs that prioritises accessibility over ability. The club’s founder, Fleur Cousens, says: “I founded the team because I was basically fed up of being told that football is a man’s game.” At training, excitement about the upcoming Women’s World Cup is palpable. “I’m going to France three weekends in a row. I’m going by ferry, train and plane. I can’t wait,” says Gaia Laidler, 24. But Cousens says more needs to be done to raise the profile of professional and grassroots women’s football. “At the women’s Euros we had to hunt down places and plead for them to put the football on,” she says. The Women’s World Cup will be a landmark moment for the sport. Fifa expects 1 billion people will tune in to watch the tournament, and in the UK the BBC will broadcast every game. “There’s a lot of excitement, awareness and anticipation that I’ve never felt before,” said Kelly Simmons, the FA’s director of women’s football. While Goal Diggers players welcome the increased coverage and sponsorship, they believe community events stressing inclusion and diversity are key to shifting perceptions. They want to ensure the increased interest in women’s football is sustained long after the World Cup ends. The club has partnered with bars, brands, and nonprofits to create the Festival of Football. As well as film screenings, panel talks and photography exhibitions, the festival will have football taster days for beginners and women over 40. “The more people see women’s football being screened in pubs and bars, the more people think that’s something they can do. The more spaces there are for women to play football, the more they are inclined to watch it,” said the festival’s founder, Hannah Wright. Jenna al-Ansari, who runs cultural events at the Book Club, a bar in east London, said the decision to screen every match was a no-brainer. “The Women’s World Cup didn’t really have a home. There isn’t a particular bar or a particular pub that had embraced the World Cup and we thought we’d be perfect for that.” She said women’s football was no longer a “niche interest that can be brushed under the carpet” and it was important fans had a place to go where there would be an atmosphere. Cousens first started playing football in primary school. “I played in a mixed team and got pushed out because I was a girl, though I was one of the best in the team. I was about nine and at that age that rejection meant I stopped playing. I thought it wasn’t a sport for me,” she says. It’s a story that resonated with other players at Goal Diggers. Amy Lester, who is training to be a coach, says the club’s greatest achievements are not matches won but the growing number of women and non-binary people who become more confident and skilled. The club is struggling to find a council willing to provide a larger pitch space. Cousens says it isn’t good enough for local authorities committed to gender equality to say bookings are on a first come, first served basis, allowing a handful of guys to block-book pitches months in advance. Angela Murdock, whose 13-year-old daughter Ruby plays for Crystal Palace under-15s, says it requires a great deal of time and effort from parents to nurture their child’s interest in the sport. “It’s a hell of a lot of driving to get them to games and training,” she says, adding that more clubs and opportunities would be welcomed. As for Ruby, she says it never crossed her mind that football wasn’t for girls. “I’ve grown up with really good female players and I’ve always thought girls could play,” she says. When she was school, some boys initially didn’t to pass to her, but that didn’t last long. “They all started to pass to me when they realised I could play.”
